data.q: What does it mean that Tailwind CSS is a 'utility-first' framework?
o: It focuses on pre-built components like Modals and Navbars
It provides low-level CSS classes that let you build custom designs directly in your HTML
It is designed primarily for building command-line utilities
It automatically writes your CSS based on your JavaScript logic
data.e: Utility-first means instead of writing custom CSS, you apply pre-defined classes (e.g., `flex`, `pt-4`, `text-center`) to compose your design.

data.q: How do you apply a hover effect to an element in Tailwind?
data.e: Tailwind uses modifiers like `hover:`, `focus:`, and `active:` to apply styles based on the element's state.

data.q: What is the purpose of the `tailwind.config.js` file?
o: To store the compiled CSS output
To customize the default theme, add plugins, and define design tokens
To list all the HTML files in the project
data.e: This file is the heart of Tailwind customization, allowing you to define your own colors, spacing, breakpoints, and more.

data.q: In Tailwind, which class prefix is used to create responsive designs that target screens larger than 768px (tablets)?
data.e: The `md:` prefix targets the 'medium' breakpoint, which defaults to 768px in the standard Tailwind configuration.

data.q: What does the 'Just-in-Time' (JIT) engine do in Tailwind?
o: It compiles all possible CSS classes at the start of a project
It generates CSS on-demand as you write your HTML, keeping the file size minimal
It automatically optimizes images for faster loading
It translates CSS to JavaScript for better performance
data.e: The JIT engine scans your files for used classes and generates only the necessary CSS, enabling faster builds and arbitrarily dynamic values like `top-[117px]`.

data.q: Which utility class would you use to add a padding of 1rem (16px) to both the left and right sides of an element?
data.e: `px-4` applies padding to the x-axis (left and right). By default, `4` translates to `1rem` in Tailwind's spacing scale.

data.q: How can you apply a style specifically for Dark Mode users in Tailwind?
data.e: By using the `dark:` modifier, you can easily style elements for dark mode, which is triggered by either system settings or a class on the `<html>` element.

data.q: What is the 'Box Shadow' utility class to add a large shadow to an element?
data.e: `shadow-lg` is the standard Tailwind utility for a large box shadow. `shadow-xl` and `shadow-2xl` are also available for even larger shadows.

data.q: Which Tailwind directive is used in your CSS file to inject Tailwind's base, components, and utilities styles?
data.e: These `@tailwind` directives are replaced by the Tailwind CLI with the actual generated CSS during the build process.

data.q: How do you specify a custom, one-off color value like `#ff5733` using Tailwind's arbitrary value syntax?
data.e: Square brackets `[]` allow you to use arbitrary values that aren't defined in your theme, generating a specific class for that value on the fly.

data.q: What does the `group` class do when used with a modifier like `group-hover:text-blue-500`?
o: It groups multiple elements together in a flexbox
It allows you to style a child element when its parent (the 'group') is hovered
It applies the same style to all elements with that class
It creates a CSS Grid group
data.e: The `group` class is placed on a container, allowing children to respond to the container's state using `group-hover`, `group-focus`, etc.

data.q: What is the purpose of the `content` array in the `tailwind.config.js` file?
o: To list the text content of the website
To specify the paths to all of your template files so Tailwind can scan them for used classes
To define the HTML meta tags
data.e: The `content` array tells Tailwind which files to watch and scan, ensuring that the JIT engine generates CSS for every class you use.
